content:
Diagnosis:	Squamous cell carcinoma of hypopharynx (pyriform fossa)

Management:	15 Mar 2024 Diagnostic panendoscopy and biopsy

Histology:	Moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, p16 negative

Staging:	T3N1M0 (Stage III)

Current Situation:	Post-operative assessment prior to definitive treatment

I reviewed [redacted name] today following his recent diagnosis of hypopharyngeal cancer. The initial presenting symptoms were progressive dysphagia to solids over 3 months and a right-sided neck lump noticed 6 weeks ago. He denies any weight loss or voice changes. His performance status remains excellent at PS 0.

Imaging shows a 4.2cm primary tumor involving the right pyriform fossa with a single ipsilateral level II lymph node measuring 2.1cm. CT chest and upper abdomen show no evidence of distant metastatic disease.

On examination today, flexible nasendoscopy shows the previously documented tumor in the right pyriform fossa with normal vocal cord movement bilaterally. The right level II node remains palpable but mobile.

I have discussed his case at our Head and Neck MDT on 20th March. The consensus recommendation is for primary chemoradiotherapy with concurrent cisplatin. I have explained the treatment process, including the need for a prophylactic feeding tube placement. He will require dental assessment and radiotherapy planning CT next week.

The plan is to commence treatment in 2 weeks' time. We will arrange weekly reviews during treatment in our combined Head and Neck clinic. I have provided written information about chemoradiotherapy and arranged for our specialist nurse to discuss supportive care.

primary_cancer.metastases: single ipsilateral level II lymph node

cancer_timeline.value: 4.2cm primary tumor in right pyriform fossa with 2.1cm level II lymph node
Biopsy confirms moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, p16 negative
Head and Neck MDT recommendation for primary chemoradiotherapy

patient_facts.value: Progressive dysphagia to solids over 3 months
Tumor in right pyriform fossa with normal vocal cord movement, palpable but mobile right level II node
CT chest and upper abdomen show no evidence of distant metastatic disease

status_updates.value: Newly diagnosed stage III hypopharyngeal cancer. Initial assessment following diagnostic biopsy, planned for definitive chemoradiotherapy.
Plan to commence concurrent cisplatin chemoradiotherapy
Dental assessment and radiotherapy planning CT next week
Weekly reviews during treatment in combined Head and Neck clinic
